message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Heuristic Evaluation of Conversational Agents
Paper Abstract: Conversational interfaces have risen in popularity as businesses and users adopt a range of conversational agents, including chatbots and voice assistants. Although guidelines have been proposed, there is not yet an established set of usability heuristics to guide and evaluate conversational agent design. In this paper, we propose a set of heuristics for conversational agents adapted from Nielsen's heuristics and based on expert feedback. We then validate the heuristics through two rounds of evaluations conducted by participants on two conversational agents, one chatbot and one voice-based personal assistant. We find that, when using our heuristics to evaluate both interfaces, evaluators were able to identify more usability issues than when using Nielsen's heuristics. We propose that our heuristics successfully identify issues related to dialogue content, interaction design, help and guidance, human-like characteristics, and data privacy.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed a web search for "Conversational agent chatbot" and found comprehensive information. Here are the key results:

## Definition

A chatbot is a software application or web interface designed to have textual or spoken conversations, and modern chatbots typically use generative artificial intelligence systems that are capable of maintaining a conversation with a user in natural language and simulating how a human would behave as a conversational partner.

## Modern Technology

In the 2020s, dialogue systems have increasingly been built on top of large language models (LLMs), which allow them to handle open-domain conversation more flexibly than earlier rule-based or statistical approaches.(no content)AI chatbots typically use a foundational large language model, such as GPT-4 or the Gemini language model, which is fine-tuned for specific uses.

## Applications

Conversational agents are being embedded into applications with user-friendly interfaces for customer service, education, and personal assistance.(no content)A major area where chatbots have long been used is customer service and support, with various sorts of virtual assistants.

## Interface Types

Modern implementations often integrate both voice and text interfaces, providing users with multi-modal interaction through conversational agents.

I've completed a web search for "Conversational agent chatbot" and found comprehensive information. Here are the key results:

## Definition

A chatbot is a software application or web interface designed to have textual or spoken conversations, and modern chatbots typically use generative artificial intelligence systems that are capable of maintaining a conversation with a user in natural language and simulating how a human would behave as a conversational partner.

## Modern Technology

In the 2020s, dialogue systems have increasingly been built on top of large language models (LLMs), which allow them to handle open-domain conversation more flexibly than earlier rule-based or statistical approaches.(no content)AI chatbots typically use a foundational large language model, such as GPT-4 or the Gemini language model, which is fine-tuned for specific uses.

## Applications

Conversational agents are being embedded into applications with user-friendly interfaces for customer service, education, and personal assistance.(no content)A major area where chatbots have long been used is customer service and support, with various sorts of virtual assistants.

## Interface Types

Modern implementations often integrate both voice and text interfaces, providing users with multi-modal interaction through conversational agents.

I've found comprehensive information about human-computer interaction. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".

## Key Concepts

The term is intended to convey that, unlike other tools with specific and limited uses, computers have many uses which often involve an open-ended dialogue between the user and the computer.(no content)Humans interact with computers in many ways, and the interface between the two is crucial to facilitating this interaction.

## Interdisciplinary Nature

Because human–computer interaction studies a human and a machine in communication, it draws from supporting knowledge on both the machine and the human side. On the machine side, techniques in computer graphics, operating systems, programming languages, and development environments are relevant. On the human side, communication theory, graphic and industrial design disciplines, linguistics, social sciences, cognitive psychology, social psychology, and human factors such as computer user satisfaction are relevant.

## Historical Context

The first known use was in 1975 by Carlisle.

## Interaction Approaches

The field encompasses various interaction methods including gesture recognition, facial expression analysis, body movement tracking, and gaze detection, all contributing to enhancing human-computer interaction.

Human-computer interaction remains a vital field as technology continues to evolve and become more integrated into everyday life.

Links: [{"title":"Virtual assistant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_assistant"},{"title":"Google Assistant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Assistant"},{"title":"Bixby (software) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bixby_(software)"},{"title":"Siri - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siri"},{"title":"Cortana (Halo) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cortana_(Halo)"},{"title":"Gender digital divide - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Female_gendering_of_AI_technologies"},{"title":"Voice assistants - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Voice_assistants&redirect=no"},{"title":"Lyra (virtual assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyra_(virtual_assistant)"},{"title":"Celia (virtual assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celia_(virtual_assistant)"},{"title":"Mycroft (software) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mycroft_(software)"}]

Here are the web search results for "voice assistant":

## Overview

A virtual assistant is a software agent that can perform a range of tasks or services for a user based on user input, such as commands or questions, including verbal ones.(no content)Such technologies often incorporate chatbot capabilities to streamline task execution.

## Major Voice Assistants

The most popular voice assistants today include:

- **Siri**: Siri is a virtual assistant and chatbot purchased, developed, and popularized by Apple Inc., which is included in the iOS, iPadOS, watchOS, macOS, Apple TV, audioOS, and visionOS operating systems.

- **Google Assistant**: Users primarily interact with Google Assistant through natural voice, and it is able to answer questions, schedule events and alarms, adjust hardware settings on the user's device, show information from the user's Google account, and play games.

- **Bixby**: Bixby is a voice assistant developed by Samsung that provides device control, information retrieval, and task automation using voice input and artificial intelligence, and can answer contextual queries, adjust system settings, perform searches, and manage reminders or schedules.

## Technology and Capabilities

Virtual assistants use natural language processing (NLP) to match user text or voice input to executable commands.(no content)Voice assistants now manage upwards of 1 billion tasks per month, from the mundane (changing a song) to the essential (contacting emergency services).

Web search results for query: "heuristic evaluation usability"

Links: [{"title":"Heuristic evaluation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heuristic_evaluation"},{"title":"Usability inspection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usability_inspection"},{"title":"Jakob Nielsen (usability consultant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakob_Nielsen_(usability_consultant)"},{"title":"Cognitive walkthrough - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_walkthrough"},{"title":"Usability testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usability_testing"},{"title":"Usability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User-friendliness"},{"title":"Usability engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usability_engineering"},{"title":"Comparison of usability evaluation methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_usability_evaluation_methods"},{"title":"Web usability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_usability"},{"title":"HeuristicLab - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HeuristicLab"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about heuristic evaluation usability:

## Overview

A heuristic evaluation is a usability inspection method for computer software that helps to identify usability problems in the user interface design.(no content)It specifically involves evaluators examining the interface and judging its compliance with recognized usability principles (the "heuristics").

## How It Works

It involves having a small set of evaluators examining the interface and using recognized usability principles (the "heuristics"). It is the most popular of the usability inspection methods, as it is quick, cheap, and easy.

## Development

Usability consultants Rolf Molich and Jakob Nielsen developed this method on the basis of several years of experience in teaching and consulting about usability engineering.(no content)Jakob Nielsen's list of ten heuristics is the most commonly used in industry.

## Advantages and Timing

The simplicity of heuristic evaluation is beneficial at the early stages of design and prior to user-based testing. This usability inspection method does not rely on users which can be burdensome due to the need for recruiting, scheduling issues, a place to perform the evaluation, and a payment for participant time.

## Limitations

Although heuristic evaluation can uncover many major usability issues in a short period of time, a criticism that is often leveled is that results are highly influenced by the knowledge of the expert reviewer(s).

Links: [{"title":"Heuristic evaluation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heuristic_evaluation"},{"title":"Usability inspection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usability_inspection"},{"title":"Jakob Nielsen (usability consultant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakob_Nielsen_(usability_consultant)"},{"title":"Cognitive walkthrough - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_walkthrough"},{"title":"Usability testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usability_testing"},{"title":"Usability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User-friendliness"},{"title":"Usability engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usability_engineering"},{"title":"Comparison of usability evaluation methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_usability_evaluation_methods"},{"title":"Web usability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_usability"},{"title":"HeuristicLab - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HeuristicLab"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about heuristic evaluation usability:

## Overview

A heuristic evaluation is a usability inspection method for computer software that helps to identify usability problems in the user interface design.(no content)It specifically involves evaluators examining the interface and judging its compliance with recognized usability principles (the "heuristics").

## How It Works

It involves having a small set of evaluators examining the interface and using recognized usability principles (the "heuristics"). It is the most popular of the usability inspection methods, as it is quick, cheap, and easy.

## Development

Usability consultants Rolf Molich and Jakob Nielsen developed this method on the basis of several years of experience in teaching and consulting about usability engineering.(no content)Jakob Nielsen's list of ten heuristics is the most commonly used in industry.

## Advantages and Timing

The simplicity of heuristic evaluation is beneficial at the early stages of design and prior to user-based testing. This usability inspection method does not rely on users which can be burdensome due to the need for recruiting, scheduling issues, a place to perform the evaluation, and a payment for participant time.

## Limitations

Although heuristic evaluation can uncover many major usability issues in a short period of time, a criticism that is often leveled is that results are highly influenced by the knowledge of the expert reviewer(s).

I've completed a web search for "user interface design." Here's what I found:

## Overview

User interface (UI) design is the design of user interfaces for machines and software, such as computers, home appliances, mobile devices, and other electronic devices, with the focus on maximizing usability and the user experience.

## Core Purpose and Goal

The goal of user interface design is to make the user's interaction as simple and efficient as possible, in terms of accomplishing user goals (user-centered design).(no content)Good user interface design facilitates finishing the task at hand without drawing unnecessary attention to itself.

## Key Principles

Several important principles guide UI design:

- Design should organize the user interface purposefully, in meaningful and useful ways based on clear, consistent models that are apparent and recognizable to users.
- The design should make simple, common tasks easy, communicating clearly and simply in the user's own language.
- The design should make all needed options and materials for a given task visible without distracting the user with extraneous or redundant information.

## Related Concepts

The term UX design refers to the entire process of creating a user experience, and it's important to distinguish the total user experience from the user interface (UI), even though the UI is obviously an extremely important part of the design.(no content)The Nielsen Norman Group, co-founded by Jakob Nielsen and Don Norman in 1998, promotes user experience and interface design education, with Nielsen pioneering the interface usability movement and creating the "10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design."

Web search results for query: "dialogue system"

Links: [{"title":"Dialogue system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue_system"},{"title":"Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue_Concerning_the_Two_Chief_World_Systems"},{"title":"Spoken dialog system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spoken_dialog_system"},{"title":"Issue-based information system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Issue-based_information_system"},{"title":"Sustained Dialogue Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sustained_Dialogue_Institute"},{"title":"System (typeface) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_(typeface)"},{"title":"Production sound mixer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Production_sound_mixer"},{"title":"Theophilus Metcalfe - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theophilus_Metcalfe"},{"title":"Racial polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_polarization"},{"title":"Castle Shikigami 2 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shikigami_No_Shiro_II"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about dialogue systems:

## Definition

A dialogue system, or conversational agent (CA), is a computer system intended to converse with a human.(no content)Dialogue systems employed one or more of text, speech, graphics, haptics, gestures, and other modes for communication on both the input and output channel.

## Key Components

Principal to any dialogue system is the dialogue manager, which is a component that manages the state of the dialogue, and dialogue strategy.(no content)The semantic information is analysed by the dialogue manager, which keeps the history and state of the dialogue and manages the general flow of the conversation. Usually, the dialogue manager contacts one or more task managers, that have knowledge of the specific task domain.

## Applications

Dialogue systems can support a broad range of applications in business enterprises, education, government, healthcare, and entertainment.(no content)Simple dialogue systems are widely used to decrease the human workload in call centers. In this and other industrial telephony applications, the functionality provided by dialogue systems is known as interactive voice response or IVR.

## Modern Developments

In the 2020s, dialogue systems have increasingly been built on top of large language models (LLMs), which allow them to handle open-domain conversation more flexibly than earlier rule-based or statistical approaches.(no content)Modern implementations often integrate both voice and text interfaces, providing users with multi-modal interaction through conversational agents. Such systems are also being embedded into applications with user-friendly interfaces for customer service, education, and personal assistance.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

I found Wikipedia information on Human-Computer Interaction (HCI). Here's a summary of what the search results show:

## Definition and Overview

Human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems.(no content)Research in HCI covers the design and the use of computer technology, which focuses on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

## Scope and Disciplines

As a field of research, human–computer interaction is situated at the intersection of computer science, behavioral sciences, design, media studies, and several other fields.(no content)The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".

## Key Areas of Focus

HCI researchers observe how people interact with computers and design technologies that allow humans to interact with computers in new ways.(no content)These include visual, auditory, and tactile (haptic) feedback systems, which serve as channels for interaction in both traditional interfaces and mobile computing contexts.

## Importance

HCI ensures that humans can safely and efficiently interact with complex technologies in fields like aviation and healthcare.

Human-computer interaction continues to be an important field that bridges technology and human needs in increasingly sophisticated ways.

I found Wikipedia information on Human-Computer Interaction (HCI). Here's a summary of what the search results show:

## Definition and Overview

Human–computer interaction (HCI) is the process through which people operate and engage with computer systems.(no content)Research in HCI covers the design and the use of computer technology, which focuses on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

## Scope and Disciplines

As a field of research, human–computer interaction is situated at the intersection of computer science, behavioral sciences, design, media studies, and several other fields.(no content)The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) defines human–computer interaction as "a discipline that is concerned with the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them".

## Key Areas of Focus

HCI researchers observe how people interact with computers and design technologies that allow humans to interact with computers in new ways.(no content)These include visual, auditory, and tactile (haptic) feedback systems, which serve as channels for interaction in both traditional interfaces and mobile computing contexts.

## Importance

HCI ensures that humans can safely and efficiently interact with complex technologies in fields like aviation and healthcare.

Human-computer interaction continues to be an important field that bridges technology and human needs in increasingly sophisticated ways.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks are now complete. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Key Findings:**

The paper "Heuristic Evaluation of Conversational Agents" proposes a novel set of usability heuristics specifically designed for evaluating conversational agents. The analysis identified **7 core triples**:

1. **Chatbot** (artifact) - Evaluated as one type of conversational interface
2. **Virtual assistant** (artifact) - Evaluated as a voice-based conversational interface  
3. **Heuristic evaluation** (method) - The foundational methodology adapted for conversational agents
4. **Dialogue system** (concept) - Underlying technical framework for conversational interaction
5. **User interface design** (concept) - Domain where the heuristics apply
6. **Human-computer interaction** (concept) - Field that benefits from the contribution
7. **Usability** (concept) - The key property being evaluated with the new heuristics

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed
- Paper Type: contribution
- Total Triples: 7
- Entity Type Distribution: 2 artifacts, 1 method, 4 concepts

The triples_output.json file has been successfully validated and is ready for use.

Sources:
- [Chatbot - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot)
- [Virtual assistant - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_assistant)
- [Heuristic evaluation - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heuristic_evaluation)
- [Dialogue system - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue_system)
- [User interface design - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_interface_design)
- [Human-computer interaction - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human%E2%80%93computer_interaction)
- [Usability - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User-friendliness)

message_metadata.final_result:
Perfect! All tasks are now complete. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Key Findings:**

The paper "Heuristic Evaluation of Conversational Agents" proposes a novel set of usability heuristics specifically designed for evaluating conversational agents. The analysis identified **7 core triples**:

1. **Chatbot** (artifact) - Evaluated as one type of conversational interface
2. **Virtual assistant** (artifact) - Evaluated as a voice-based conversational interface  
3. **Heuristic evaluation** (method) - The foundational methodology adapted for conversational agents
4. **Dialogue system** (concept) - Underlying technical framework for conversational interaction
5. **User interface design** (concept) - Domain where the heuristics apply
6. **Human-computer interaction** (concept) - Field that benefits from the contribution
7. **Usability** (concept) - The key property being evaluated with the new heuristics

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed
- Paper Type: contribution
- Total Triples: 7
- Entity Type Distribution: 2 artifacts, 1 method, 4 concepts

The triples_output.json file has been successfully validated and is ready for use.

Sources:
- [Chatbot - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot)
- [Virtual assistant - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_assistant)
- [Heuristic evaluation - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heuristic_evaluation)
- [Dialogue system - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue_system)
- [User interface design - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_interface_design)
- [Human-computer interaction - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human%E2%80%93computer_interaction)
- [Usability - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User-friendliness)
